reasoning: The critique targets one supporting move in the post (Counterargument 4: that accounting for smarter/faster researchers should push ρ upward). This is not core to the overall anti-bottleneck case because the author offers many independent reasons to doubt importing economy-wide ρ and to expect higher substitutability in AI R&D; so centrality is modest. On the attacked point itself, the critique is fairly strong: it correctly notes that treating L as simultaneously “more copies,” “higher quality,” and “faster thinking” can mask different substitution relationships with compute, so the inference “therefore ρ should be higher” is under-argued without a model/disaggregation. However, it doesn’t fully refute the author’s intended move because the author could reasonably define L as ‘effective cognitive labor’ and still argue (with additional justification) that effective-labor increases might face weaker compute complementarity than typical labor increases. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Cognitive labor quality and quantity may have different substitutability with compute
